725056f-a.text:
19th Avenue, south side, just east of Hazen Street. The view is southeastward toward 19th noad, the Old Bowery Bay Road, and shows the Isaac Rapelye farmhouse and the small cemetery adjoining the house. Rapelye bought the land in 180O. A tombstone standing in the cemetery bears the name of Abraham Rycher, born 1691, died 1770. On the extreme right of view 3
is the chimney of the old pumping station.
Views 1,2,3

725057f-b.text:
19th Avenue, south side, east from Hazen Street, showing part of this old Bowery Bay section and the trolley tracks which led to North Beach. Fenced in is the old Rapelye family burying-ground on the other side of which is one of the Rapelye homes, a colonial structure. The house fronts on 19th Road, the old Bowery Bay Road. The funnel in the background is part is part of an old pumpiing station, just this side of the boundary between Long Island City and Newtown. 19th Avenue is the former
Riker Avenue.
Views 1,2: Eugene L. Armbruster Collection  1925
Views 3,4: P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS  June 3, 1927

725076f-a.text:
19th Road, north side, between Hasen Street (left) and Nineteenth Ave. (right), just west of an old pumping station. Behind this house is an old cemetery. This is stated to be one of the oldest houses in Newtown, standing in part of town, now Long Island City, on Bowery Bay. This place was erected about 1650 by Harck SSiboutsen and left by his son Jacobus to his nephew Abram Lent in 1729. From the Lent family it passed to the Rapelye family. Isaac Rapelye owned and occupied it prioe to 185E. See Annals of Newtown
by J. Riker for more data.
T Date.
Arthur White.

725077f-b.text:
19th Road, north side, east from Hazen Street, to Nireteenth Avenue, showing in a set of four views the Rapelje house. Abraham Rycken (born 1691; died 1770) erected the original house. The center room of the present house is said to be a part of the original structure. See other views for more data.
March 1925
Views 1,2 and 3
View 41 May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

725078f-b.text:
19th Road, north side, east from Hazen Street to Nineteenth Avenues, showing in 4 views the Rapelje house. Bowery Bay Cemetery in the rear of the house contains markers of the 18th century for members of the Rapelje, Cornell, Riker, MIyster and other families. Chas. Rapelje (born 1785), purchased in 1830 the farm formerly owned by Daniel Riker. The estate of Cnas.Tapelje, subsequent to his death in 1834, was given to his children David P., lIsaac C., Catherine M., and Lavina P. Rapelje. The center room of this house was erected by Abraham Rycken who was the son of a first settler. He died in 1770. Daniel Riker who inherited it from his father Jacobus sold it in 1827 to Charles hapelje. This house stands on the probable aite of the Harek Siboutsen house. He settled here in 1650. In 1729 his son dacobus willed the farm to his nephew Abraham Lent. Futher history concerning these families and their properties rmay be found in the 'Annals of Newtown", written by one Riker in 1852.
Fay 1929
View 2: 1922
View 2&:3:March 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
